title: External node provider does not work with multinode
body:
The Ray autoscaler fails to work with the external node provider. This is a known issue:

> Is it working for the multinode? As our [gang_scheduling for multinode](https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/f317d3ee2e18a93f71cfff01f3767467cd6c3cf1/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L784) will first provision the instance with only the setup code in the first line `pip3 install -U ray[default]...` using `ray up`. After the instances are created, we will do the `ray up` again with all the setup commands. Is it ok that the `node_provider` be installed in the second `ray up`? If not, we can move this `pip3 install -e "{{skylet_remote_path}}"` to L91, and add the file_mounts of the `skylet` folder into the first provision of gang_scheduling.

_Originally posted by @Michaelvll in https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/pull/178#discussion_r784380415_

title: Sky exec doesn't use multi-CPU?
body:
I submitted my job by `sky exec` but looks like it's only using 1 CPU-core for my matrix computation by PyTorch Sparse.
This is different from directly running the same run commend on the server which uses all CPU-core (10x performance difference in this case).
Is it an expected behavior?

title: Cloud storage for multi-nodes
body: Cloud storage mounting may need to be able to download the cloud storage to worker nodes as well in multi-node situations.

title: Stopped (AWS) clusters cannot be actually terminated (Ray bug)
body:
To repro
```bash
sky launch -c debug examples/minimal.yaml           

# Wait until UI changes from Stopping to Stopped.
sky stop debug   

# This has no actual effect, as seen in the AWS UI -- cluster remains in Stopped.
# `sky status` removed the cluster entry, so it is now leaked.
sky down debug
```
Ray output for the last command --- note that there's no "terminating 1 node(s)` message:
```
2022-01-24 11:36:37,197 INFO util.py:282 -- setting max workers for head node type to 0
Loaded cached provider configuration
If you experience issues with the cloud provider, try re-running the command with --no-config-cache.
Destroying cluster. Confirm [y/N]: y [automatic, due to --yes]
2022-01-24 11:36:37,324 INFO util.py:282 -- setting max workers for head node type to 0
Exception occurred when stopping the cluster Ray runtime (use -v to dump teardown exceptions).
Ignoring the exception and attempting to shut down the cluster nodes anyway.
No nodes remaining.
Terminating cluster debug...done.
```

This is a Ray bug.  

Note that I've tried to change the code [here](https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/master/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L1510) to 
```python
            config['provider']['cache_stopped_nodes'] = not terminate

            cluster_status = global_user_state.get_status_from_cluster_name(
                cluster_name)
            if (cluster_status == global_user_state.ClusterStatus.STOPPED and
                    terminate):
                config['provider']['cache_stopped_nodes'] = True
```
i.e., I tried both of `cache_stopped_nodes: {True, False}` when `sky down`-ing a stopped cluster, but both didn't have any effect.  Ray AWSNodeProvider's terminate logic probably didn't consider stopped nodes.

/cc @suquark

title: Fix the source ~/.bashrc not working problem
body:
This PR fixes the following problem:
1. `sky gpunode` and do `echo export TEST_VAR="test" >> ~/.bashrc`.
2. `sky exec -c sky-gpunode-username --gpus K80:1 -- "source ~/.bashrc && echo TEST_VAR \$TEST_VAR".`
Our original code will not print out the `$TEST_VAR`, since `source ~/.bashrc` does not work when the `-i` option is not given. This will cause problems when users add things in `~/.bashrc` during setup, and want to use them during `run`, e.g. adding `WANDB_API_KEY` to the `~/.bashrc`.

title: skylet_wheels will not be updated when skylet code changes
body: Since we are using the same version number, even if the skylet code changes during our development, `sky launch -c existing_cluster yaml` will not update the skylet code on the remote instance, which makes it quite inconvenient developing the code in job_lib, etc.

title: Fix the aws spot price data in catalog
body: The original method for fetching aws spot instance prices cannot get all the prices, e.g. it did not include the us-west-2 spot price for p3.16xlarge.

title: Fix defunct job after cancelling
body:
We are currently using `subprocess` to run the command line. The child process may be defunct when the python program is killed. Fixed by creating a subprocess to kill the defuncted child process with `try ... finally`. Fixed #233 

Tested:
1. Launch a cluster with `sky launch -c test ./examples/job_queue/cluster.yaml`
2. Run a GPU program `sky exec -c test ./examples/job_queue/job_gpu.yaml`
3. Check the gpustat `sky exec -c test gpustat`
3. Cancel the job `sky cancel -c test 1`
4. Check the gpustat again `sky exec -c test gpustat -cpu -i 1`

Before the fix, the gpu will remain occupied after canceling. After the fix, the problem is solved.

title: Remove git SSH forwarding
body:
Adding git SSH forwarding has proven very difficult to test consistently and has been unreliable for different setups. Since we cannot support remotes that aren't GitHub easily nor can we support HTTPS auth forwarding, I am removing this automatic forwarding feature for now. 

The recommended approaches are either to set up ssh agent forwarding yourself (with [GitHub's tutorial](https://docs.github.com/en/developers/overview/using-ssh-agent-forwarding)) or to use their `gh auth` tool which works very well.

Closes #231. Closes #223.

### Tests
Ran smoke tests with no issues.

title: Add job start time and fix the last used command for the cluster
body:
Main changes:
1. Add a `STARTED` column to the job queue, so that the user can know when the job is scheduled and started to run. #226 
2. Fix the last used command in the cluster status for `sky exec`.
3. Fix the wheel directory with username. #227 
4. Fix the using python2 to build wheel on AWS cpunode problem. #221

body:
There are some model checkpoint directory (~10GB) or `wandb` under my working directory, which I don't really want to upload and slowed down the progress. I had to manually move them out which is pretty inconvenient.
Is it possible to specify directories that will be excluded during code sync? perhaps by passing arguments to `rsync --exclude`?

title: Add task.name checks
body:
Adds check if task.name is valid.

Valid task name is defined as either NoneType or str with ASCII characters which may contain lowercase and uppercase letters, digits, underscores, periods, and dashes. Must start and end with alphanumeric characters. No triple dashes or underscores.

Currently also allows `None` as a valid task name (even though it's not supported by Docker. However, I have allowed it for now since not allowing task.name=None is a bigger change that requires discussion. 

Fixes #222.

title: LocalDockerBackend does not support special characters in image name
body:
Docker does not support special characters in image name, so tasks which use special characters as `task.name` fail. E.g. `sky launch --docker 'echo hello'` fails because the CLI assigns it the name `<cmd>`

https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/135514417abcf48c553bdc9a22cefccc2b024c48/prototype/sky/cli.py#L375

title: Sky storage downloads the folder from cloud storage to the path a level deeper
body:
The cloud storage will sync the folder to `~/test/test` on the remote instance if the `~/test` folder already exists with the following yaml.
```yaml
resources:
  cloud: was

storage:
- name: test
    source: /tmp/test

storage_mounts:
- storage: test
    mount_path: ~/test
```

title: Restart interactive node with node command after stopping
body:
Closes #214. This change allows sky to restart a gpunode after it has been stopped using gpunode directly:

### Tested
Passes everything below and smoke tests
```
sky gpunode --cloud aws --gpus V100
sky stop sky-gpunode-gautam
sky gpunode

sky stop sky-gpunode-gautam
sky start sky-gpunode-gautam

sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus V100 --cloud aws # should succeed first time
sky gpunode -c t1                                             # should login
sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus K80                        # should error with this change
sky cpunode -c t1                                             # should error with this change
sky tpunode -c t1                                              # should error
sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus V100 --cloud aws # should login

sky gpunode -c t2 --cloud aws --gpus V100
sky stop t2
sky gpunode -c t2 --cloud gcp  # errors
```

title: Only retry the original region when restarting cluster
body:
This PR partially solves the problem in #205 . We should not retry different regions when we are restarting a stopped cluster, since the attached volumes will be invisible in other regions.

The problem is hard to reproduce, so I manually tested the newly added function in `global_user_state.py` with an existing cluster_name, and the yield/raise execution order.
```python
>>> # The function correctly fetches the cluster status
>>> cluster_status = global_user_state.get_status_from_cluster_name('my-test')
>>> cluster_status == global_user_state.ClusterStatus.STOPPED
False
>>> cluster_status == global_user_state.ClusterStatus.UP
True
```
```python
>>> # The error raising will only be executed after the caller function requires 
>>> # the next item in the generator
>>> def gen():                                                                       
...     yield 1                                                                      
...     raise A                                                                      
...                                                                                  
>>> for i in gen():
...     print('1')
...     time.sleep(2)
...     print('2')
... 
1
2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<stdin>", line 3, in gen
NameError: name 'A' is not defined
```

Future TODO: the `boto3` will keep retrying to start the cluster (max 12 times), and will take more than 40 mins before raising the error.

title: Bump yapf from 0.27 to 0.32.
Interactive inline commands does not work, e.g. `sky exec -- htop`
body:
Due to the logging limitation, our job queue does not support interactive commands, such as `htop`. 

#197 and #207 may mitigate this problem by directly running the interactive code with `ssh`.

title: Refactor write_cluster_config in backend_utils.py
body: This function is getting crazy large with too many things going on.

title: Directly run the inline cmd on cluster without job queue
body:
This PR tends to make the `sky exec -c cluster "inline cmd"` faster without using the job queue. #197 

Proposal:
1. `sky exec -c cluster "inline cmd"`
    - The user means to run the comment immediately, so we directly run it through `ssh`, e.g. `sky exec -c cluster ls`.
    - Claim: The user should take responsibility that her inline command will not take other running tasks' resources when the resources option is not set, e.g. `srun --nodelist=blaze "inline cmd"` will not guarantee the task does not use GPU resources`.
    - This also solves the problem in #209. The user now can do `sky exec -c cluster -- htop`.
2. `sky exec -c cluster --gpus=V100:1 "inline cmd"` #200 
    - The user wants the resources to be guaranteed, so it will still use the job queue implementation.

Cons:
1. This will make the behavior of `sky exec -c cluster -- "cmd"` different from `sky exec -c cluster --gpus=V100:1 -- "cmd"`. The former one will not use job queue and will be interactive (Ctrl+C works), but the latter one will use the job queue and be non-interactive.

To decide (not sure if that would be a real use case):
1. The user may want to run an inline CPU command in a job queue.

FYI, cc @gmittal 

Tested:
- [x] `sky exec -c cluster -- htop`; `sky exec -c cluster htop` 
- [x] `sky exec -c cluster -- gpustat -cpu -i 1`
- [x] `sky exec -c cluster -- ls`; `sky exec -c cluster ls`

title: Fix the `-tt` option for ssh command while not in interactive mode
body:
https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/9e0703ddbd7dd5782bd7635fb35b79c993ec329d/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L1590
`ssh_head_command` will have a `-tt` option for the ssh command, which will force pseudo-terminal allocation for the connection. Switch to `-T` (disable pseudo-terminal allocation) for non-interactive mode solves the following problems:

1. It makes `sky exec -c jq -d examples/job_queue/job.yaml &` work. (Previously, we will have following error: `[1]  + 98936 suspended (tty output)  sky exec -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml > /dev/null`)
2. It resolve the problem we met before that the return value of ssh command was corrupted by keyboard input #196. 
  > when we get the output from the ssh subprocess, the keyboard input will appear in the stdout, like the following error (I type in `llhkukjbkubkiu`, when the program is fetching the job id). After adding the encoding and decoding, the problem is solved.
  ```bash
  ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'llhkukjbkubkiu1\r\n'
  ```

Tested:

- [x] `sky cpunode`

title: Do not use job submission for inline commands in `sky exec`
body:
We should use ssh_run_command for inline commands if the user does not specify the resources, instead of using job submission for the `sky exec`.

Pros:
The inline commands should be executed efficiently, e.g. `sky exec -c cluster ls`, but job submission will create some overheads.

Cons:
We need to figure out a way to make it ssh_run_command not interactive to make the behavior consistent when the user specifies the resources inline.

Note: We can still add the inline command into the job queue to make it more traceable.

title: Fix skylet setup issue (skylet failed to be imported locally by a third-party package)
body:
Closes #192
Closes #194
Closes #198

In our current architecture, there are 3 cases we need global public access to sky package:

1. When spinning up a cluster, we call ray autoscaler. When using a custom cloud provider contained in sky (we need it to support key features not available in Ray, e.g., start/stop GCP and Azure, TPU non-vm instances), Ray will access a globally available python module.
2. Job queue and logging support in the cluster need access to some sky modules. These modules are also used by sky locally.
3. Ray autoscaler in the cluster need access to the cloud provider contained in sky.

There are 3 solutions:

1. Publish sky to pypi or make sky open accessible on github, so we have public access to the sky package. This is the solution of Ray autoscaler - you need to install Ray in the remote cluster from pypi or from a downloadable wheel.
2. Mount the entire sky package to the cluster. This package is not installable after mounting, so we need to further modify it (e.g. add a setup.py) and install it. Not sure this is achievable with our yaml file.
3. A separate package contained in sky called “skylet”. This is the current workaround. We can copy it to the cluster and install it directly. The drawback is that we need to ask the developers/contributors to install both sky and skylet; this is because for development, skylet and sky are installed with `editable` mode, with this mode we cannot directly install skylet when installing sky.

I think finally we would converge to solution 1. So I build the workaround based on solution 1.

This workaround builds a python wheel for sky locally and uploads it to the cluster. Then it installs sky in the cluster.

title: Disable workdir sync for interactive nodes
body:
This is to address #135.

After discussion with @Michaelvll, it seems that `--sync` has slightly confusing semantics, since it only runs on cluster init. Additionally, what if you want to sync down or sync up? What if you want to a sync a workdir that's not the current directory. While we could design a custom solution that satisfies these requirements, it is much simpler for a user to use `rsync`, so we `rsync` examples in help strings everywhere.

### Tests
- [x] No longer syncs workdir
- [x] `rsync` commands work

title: Make 'setup failed -> fix setup, rerun sky launch' work for 1-node.
body:
Bug nature:
- from a state where ray processes aren't up (due to setup failing)
- running 'sky launch' on this state does NOT recover ray processes due to our use of `--no-restart` flag
- the cluster therefore is unusable, must be `sky stop && sky start` manually

To reproduce, use `minimal.yaml`
- sky launch -c, with `exit 1` added to `setup` 
- fix setup (remove `exit 1`)
- sky launch -c again

Before this change:
```
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:713] Successfully provisioned or found existing VM. Setup completed.
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:715]
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:715] To log into the head VM:  ssh min2
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:715]
I 01-13 16:58:16 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1271] Reserved Job ID: 1
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399]
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] Cluster name: min2
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To log into the head VM: ssh min2
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To submit a job:         sky exec -c min2 yaml_file
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To teardown the cluster: sky down min2
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To stop the cluster:     sky stop min2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/execution.py", line 133, in _execute
    backend.execute(handle, task, stream_logs, detach_run)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1296, in execute
    stream_logs, detach_run)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1336, in _execute_task_one_node
    detach_run=detach_run)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1233, in _exec_code_on_head
    check=True)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1564, in _run_command_on_head_via_ssh
    check=check)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/remote_libs/log_lib.py", line 87, in run_with_log
    raise RuntimeError('Command failed, please check the logs.')
RuntimeError: Command failed, please check the logs.
```

After this change:
- ray processes are restarted on the head, making this workflow succeed

----

**Known issue for the future: multinode recovery**
- this does not work for `multi_hostname.yaml` with injected `exit 1`
- the first `sky launch` would fail, putting the worker node forever in an `uninitialized` state, 
- ...which makes the second `sky launch` not be able to hit `_ensure_cluster_ray_started()`.

Workaround for multinode: advise users to manually `sky stop` and `sky start` after fixing the setup.

title: Tour of Sky notebook
body:
There's a lot of ground to cover and suggestions/contributions are welcome. My biggest concern right now is that the logs will just overwhelm the user (we should suppress the pip installs on cluster startup). A lot of this was inspired by @romilbhardwaj's quickstart docs. Goal was to go for something like [this](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/quickstart.html) and not something like [this](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pytrees.html).

If others are interested in contributing (and please do so!), feel free to use this as an integration branch (open PRs using this branch as the base instead of `master`).

Not all features are documented in this notebook because 1) some things are hard to demo in a notebook and 2) trivial examples for some things are a bit hard to construct and complicated to run without the notebook taking a while to get through. Since this is something a first-time user will use, we want to keep this short and reserve more advanced features/modes for a proper docs.

Potential features that should be discussed and could get their own sections:
- Storage @romilbhardwaj @michaelzhiluo 
- Job queue @Michaelvll

NOTE: to view the copy of the notebook without pulling the branch locally, [go here](https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/85077215d5adef6bd0ae84d45aa8909c8b1e9f1c/prototype/docs/tour-of-sky.ipynb)

We currently have no safeguards in place to prevent a user from changing specified resources when re-using a cluster. We can keep `launch`'s resource check logic the same because the less-than-or-equal check is reasonable behavior there but not for interactive nodes.

  Note: it seems that FIFO is an expected feature of ray, and they are trying to patch it, according to Eric. However, it may take a while for ray to fix it and publish it in the release version. Here are two possible workarounds that remain to be investigated:
  1. The placement_group manager used in the ray.tune
  2. Manually do the scheduling the placement group by storing scheduling states in the job database (as mentioned by Romil).

- [x] misalignment of \t going on. (from zongheng). [Fixed in #159.]

title: Logging problem for multiple jobs
body: A logging problem was found for the job queue. Whenever the number of jobs submitted contains [a-f] in hex, the jobs' logs will be messed up together. Ray [PR reference](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/pull/20816/files). The problem is caused by this line in ray: [v1.9.1](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/2cdbf974ea63caf4323aacbccaef2394a14a8562/python/ray/_private/log_monitor.py#L27) vs [master branch](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/34cee199b17bb152763459fceb0722fbd99886a3/python/ray/_private/log_monitor.py#L28.). It seems the problem will be solved in [v1.10.0](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/releases/1.10.0/python/ray/_private/log_monitor.py).

title: `using_file_mounts.yaml` fails due to `apt install` in setup

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
The `examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` fails due to the `sudo apt-get install -y tree` command in the setup with the following error on GCP / AWS:

```bash
E: Could not get lock /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend - open (11: Resource temporarily unavailable)                       
E: Unable to acquire the dpkg frontend lock (/var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend), is another process using it?
```

Seems like this problem is caused by the ubuntu's daily install:
```bash
ubuntu@ip-172-31-86-184:~$ ps aux | grep -i apt
root      4633  0.0  0.0   4632   784 ?        Ss   05:34   0:00 /bin/sh /usr/lib/apt/apt.systemd.daily install
root      4647  0.0  0.0   4632  1744 ?        S    05:34   0:00 /bin/sh /usr/lib/apt/apt.systemd.daily lock_is_held install
ubuntu    6845  0.0  0.0  14864  1080 pts/1    S+   05:39   0:00 grep --color=auto -i apt
```

title: Programmatic API providing similar interface as cli
body:
The current programmatic API only supports the function of `sky run`. If the user wants to `sky exec` they cannot do it (or need to touch the lower level logic as we did in `exec` cli).

Proposal: using the following two programmatic API to replace the `sky.execute()`
1. `sky.launch()`: do what we did in `sky launch/run` (same as original `sky.execute()`)
2. `sky.exec()`: do what we did in `sky exec`. (same as the following)
  ```python
                sky.execute(stages=[
                    sky.execution.Stage.SYNC_WORKDIR,
                    sky.execution.Stage.EXEC,
                ],)
  ```

title: Add agent forwarding for `sky [cpu|gpu|tpu]node` connections
body:
This fixes an issue raised by @concretevitamin.

Currently agent forwarding (for git credentials, etc.) only works when using `ssh` directly (e.g. `ssh my_cluster`). This can be confusing because `sky cpunode -c my_cluster` also provides an interactive session but agent forwarding is not present (and git operations won't work with your local SSH keys). This PR fixes that.

## Tests
- [x] Successfully cloned private repo with `sky cpunode -c my_cluster`

title: Make cluster name an argument when it is required
body:
Based on discussion/poll in Slack, the agreed upon experience makes cluster name an argument for all commands where it is required (e.g. `sky stop`, `sky cancel`, `sky exec`, and others) and `-c` where it is optional (e.g. `sky cpunode`, `sky launch`, etc.).

### Tests
Ran updated smoke tests

title: Standard python package setup
body:
This PR uses the standard python package setup. `requirements.txt` is used for manual dependency installation for a standalone project, but not for a package.

Closes #128

title: Sky Exec/Run Bash Command
body:
This PR has been split from #125. This PR is the non controversial PR (where everyone agrees on the design choice) and simply adds bash command to both `sky exec` and `sky run`. The second PR which is #125  includes `sky run --setup` and bash file as input.

Examples:
`sky run -c hello "echo hello"`

`sky exec -c hello "echo bye"`

title: Setup commands sometimes fail if it contains `apt install`
body:
For example, `examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` would sometimes fail during setup and show
```
E: Could not get lock /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend - open (11: Resource temporarily unavailable)  
E: Unable to acquire the dpkg frontend lock (/var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend),   
 is another process using it?
```

because it has a setup command

```
setup: 'sudo apt-get install -y tree'
```

This is because sometimes AWS instances would run `apt` or `dpkg` commands in the background.

Here are some solutions: https://askubuntu.com/questions/132059/how-to-make-a-package-manager-wait-if-another-instance-of-apt-is-running
